head.title: The Nambuâ€“Goto action as the one of the quantized spaceâ€“time excitation.

article.h1: The Nambuâ€“Goto action as the one of the quantized spaceâ€“time excitation.

span.span:
Serge B. Afanasâ€™ev
Sanktâ€“Petersburg, Russia
e-mail:Â serg@ptslab.ioffe.rssi.ru

div.p: The concept of the quantized spaceâ€“time of the formless finite fundamental elements is suggested. This spaceâ€“time can be defined as a set of continual spaceâ€“time coverings by simply connected nonâ€“overlapping regions of any form and arbitrary sizes with some probability measure. The functional integrating method and the spaceâ€“time action problem are analyzed. A string in this spaceâ€“time is considered as an excitation of a number of fundamental elements forming oneâ€“dimensional curve. It is possible to direct the way for the volume term of the spaceâ€“time action to yield the Nambuâ€“Goto action with this consideration.

Classical spaceâ€“time is the continuum which is an arena for particles motion at their interaction. This concept of the spaceâ€“time description remains in the quantum mechanics and the quantum field theory, where the spaceâ€“time properties do not depend on particles structure and propagation, but particles are described by wave functions that have finite values in all spaceâ€“time. Connection of the spaceâ€“time structure and the matter is shown in the theory of gravitation. Classical gravitation theory spaceâ€“time is the continuum also, but the quantum description of spaceâ€“time properties at small distances is connected with the fundamental length (lfsubscriptğ‘™ğ‘“italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:endl_{f}) existence and discrete structure of the spaceâ€“time.

The lattice spaceâ€“time with the fixed lattice is most commonly investigatedÂ [1]. But the spaceâ€“time with the fixed lattice consideration leads to several problems. The first and seemingly the most essential problem is the passage from the lattice spaceâ€“time to the continuum in the limit lfâ†’0â†’subscriptğ‘™ğ‘“0italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARROW:to NUMBER:0l_{f}\to 0. The lattice spaceâ€“time has the power of a countable set. Any subdivision of a lattice yields a set with the same power. Thus in the limit lfâ†’0â†’subscriptğ‘™ğ‘“0italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARROW:to NUMBER:0l_{f}\to 0 any lattice spaceâ€“time with any subdivision remains a set with the power of a countable set. The second, the resulting equations in the lattice space and other spaces with determined fundamental element form depend on form of a fundamental element. The third, the equations in the lattice space are non-invariant under the continual symmetry operations.

Discrete geometry has been developed in the direction of the formless fundamental element in the last thirty years. The Regge calculusÂ [3] and the spaceâ€“time foam ideaÂ [4, 5] made the first steps on this way. In refs.Â [6] the stereohedra space is investigated. This space fundamental element has some set of forms. Random lattice field theory is analyzed inÂ [2]. Quantum configuration space investigated inÂ [7] is the method of quantized spaceâ€“time description based on the notâ€“fixed â€floating latticeâ€.

The alternative approach to the particle physics geometrical base is the superstring theoryÂ [8]. Strings are fundamental objects, their excited states describe all particles. But the strings are described as the geometrical objects that propagate in the background continual spaceâ€“time. Therefore strings can be considered as the basic objects for fundamental particles description, but they cannot be considered as the fundamental units of the spaceâ€“time.

In this work the concept of the space (spaceâ€“time) that consists of the formless finite fundamental elements (FFFE) is suggested. On the one hand it makes the base for spaceâ€“time quantization. Consideration of this concept leads to the idea of the spaceâ€“time action with one of the terms proportional to the volume of FFFE. This method of spaceâ€“time quantization is a consistently geometrical approach to the physics of fundamental particles and interactions. In this spaceâ€“time the particles are excited states of the fundamental elements, and the interactions are connected with the transformations of the Riemannian spaceâ€“time of FFFEs, that describes the spaceâ€“time with particleâ€“like excitations.

On the other hand the strings in this spaceâ€“time picture can be considered as propagating excitations of any number of FFFEs, forming one- dimensional spaceâ€“like curve (in the sense of FFFE spaceâ€“time). The volume term of the spaceâ€“time action of this excitation yields the Nambuâ€“Goto action term. This picture of the quantized spaceâ€“time and the strings as this spaceâ€“time excitations enables to connect these approaches and assigns the meaning of fundamental spaceâ€“time units for the strings.

The space of FFFEs can be defined as the set of coverings of the continual space by any number of non-overlapping simply connected regions of any form and arbitrary sizes. This set is provided with the probability measure, i.e. each covering contributes to the space with some probability. This measure enables the calculations based on this coverings set. Obviously, the probability measure like that the average values of sizes of FFFEs are equal to lfsubscriptğ‘™ğ‘“italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:endl_{f}, and the average number of FFFEs localized in the continual space region by the volume Vğ‘‰italic-VV is N=[Vâ¢(lfn)-1]ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘‰superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘™ğ‘“ğ‘›1italic-N RELOP:equals OPEN:[ italic-V OPEN:( italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:]N=[V(l_{f}^{n})^{-1}]. But the configurations with the FFFEs sizes greatly different from lfsubscriptğ‘™ğ‘“italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:endl_{f} also have the finite probabilities. For example, the configurations where one fundamental element expands on all the spaceâ€“time (or investigated manifold), or the configuration of continual spaceâ€“time region itself, i.e. covering this region by points. This set of coverings have the power of continuum. Therefore limit passage from the space of FFFEs to the continual space can be carried out correctly.

The general construction for calculations on this coverings set is the continual (functional) integral. In agreement with the central idea of the continual integral theory the calculation of quantum quantities is the integrating over all possible configurations of the spaceâ€“time of FFFEs (i.e. coverings of the spaceâ€“time) with the corresponding probability measure taken into account.
Consider the general construction of a functional integral. In the plane spaceâ€“time it is:

div.p: where ğ’Ÿâ¢Vğ’Ÿğ‘‰caligraphic-D italic-V{\cal D}V is a measure on the set of coverings, Sâ¢(si)ğ‘†subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–italic-S OPEN:( italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)S(s_{i}) is the plane spaceâ€“time vacuum action, sisubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:ends_{i} is the set of the element parameters (sizes, areas, volume). Here integrating is over all coverings of the continual space by non-overlapping simply connected regions of any forms and any sizes. The average value of a function on a separate FFFE is defined by

semantics.annotation: RELOP:less-than italic-f OPEN:( OPEN:{ italic-a CLOSE:} CLOSE:) RELOP:greater-than-or-equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start INTOP:integral caligraphic-D italic-V italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-S OPEN:( italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OPEN:{ italic-a CLOSE:} POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) ARG:end ARG:start INTOP:integral caligraphic-D italic-V italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-S OPEN:( italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end PUNCT:,

div.p: where f{a}â¢(xi)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OPEN:{ italic-a CLOSE:} POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)f_{\{a\}}(x^{i}) are values of the function fğ‘“italic-ff at regions of coverings set which forms the element with FFFE spaceâ€“time coordinates {a}ğ‘OPEN:{ italic-a CLOSE:}\{a\}, fâ¢(xi)ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–italic-f OPEN:( italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)f(x^{i}) is a function defined in the continual space.

The functional integral construction requires the information about the action. The spaceâ€“time vacuum action of the Minkowski spaceâ€“time can depend on fundamental elements geometrical characteristics only: volume, mğ‘šitalic-mmâ€“dimensional areas (m<nğ‘šğ‘›italic-m RELOP:less-than italic-nm<n), sizes. Suppose that one term of the fourâ€“dimensional spaceâ€“time vacuum action is proportional to the volume of a fundamental element:

semantics.annotation: italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-v italic-a italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-A ID:Planck-constant-over-2-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-G POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-square-root ARG:start ADDOP:minus italic-eta ARG:end italic-d italic-V PUNCT:,

div.p: where Ağ´italic-AA is a numerical factor. Here dâ¢Vğ‘‘ğ‘‰italic-d italic-VdV and -Î·ğœ‚italic-square-root ARG:start ADDOP:minus italic-eta ARG:end\sqrt{-\eta} are continual space values. Integrating in (3) is over one region from some covering of the continual spaceâ€“time. This term is analogous to â€spaceâ€“time foamâ€ action proportional to the volumeÂ [4]. But this term of an action is unsufficient for description the equilibrium configuration of the spaceâ€“time of FFFE. Total actions (3) of all configurations from the set of coverings are equal. The action minimum must correspond to the classical configuration, i.e. the continual spaceâ€“time configuration in the considered case.

The complete expression for the spaceâ€“time action, meeting this requirement, must contain other terms besides the volume term. The possible term is the one proportional to the total n-1ğ‘›1italic-n ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1n-1â€“Â dimensional area of FFFE. In this supposition the vacuum spaceâ€“time action is

semantics.annotation: italic-S RELOP:equals italic-alpha SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-beta SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,

div.p: where âˆ‘isubscriptğ‘–SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sum_{i} is summarizing over all FFFEs.

Let us direct the way, on which the Nambuâ€“Goto term of the string action Â [8] might be obtained from the spaceâ€“time action (3). The expression of the action of a spaceâ€“time element for this analysis is required. This action is the average value of an action Sğ‘†italic-SS with the functional integrating (2) using. This action is denoted by SFâ¢Fâ¢Fâ¢Esubscriptğ‘†ğ¹ğ¹ğ¹ğ¸italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F italic-F italic-F italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:endS_{FFFE}:

semantics.annotation: italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F italic-F italic-F italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals RELOP:less-than italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OPEN:{ italic-a CLOSE:} POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than RELOP:equals italic-A ID:Planck-constant-over-2-pi italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F italic-F italic-F italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-square-root ARG:start ADDOP:minus italic-eta ARG:end italic-d italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-d italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-d italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-d italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end

div.p: for the fourâ€“dimensional spaceâ€“time.

A string in the spaceâ€“time of FFFEs can be considered as an excitation of a number of FFFEs forming oneâ€“dimensional spaceâ€“like structure (in the meaning of FFFE spaceâ€“time). In the own reference frame the action of this excitation is represented in the form

semantics.annotation: italic-S RELOP:equals italic-A ID:Planck-constant-over-2-pi italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F italic-F italic-F italic-E italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-square-root ARG:start ADDOP:minus italic-eta ARG:end italic-d italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-d italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-d italic-l italic-d italic-tau PUNCT:,

div.p: where Ï„ğœitalic-tau\tau is the own time, lğ‘™italic-ll is the own spaceâ€“like coordinate of an excitation, x1,x2superscriptğ‘¥1superscriptğ‘¥2italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endx^{1},x^{2} are the transverse spaceâ€“like coordinates. Here integrating is over a set of FFFEs, participated in the excitation propagation. Integrations over transverse coordinates yields the average values of FFFE sizes, i.e. lfsubscriptğ‘™ğ‘“italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:endl_{f}. In supposition lfâ‰ƒLpâ¢lsimilar-to-or-equalssubscriptğ‘™ğ‘“subscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘™italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to-or-equals italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:endl_{f}\simeq L_{pl} we might obtain (Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gamma is the twoâ€“dimensional metric tensor determinant):

semantics.annotation: italic-S RELOP:equals italic-A ID:Planck-constant-over-2-pi italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end INTOP:integral italic-d italic-l italic-d italic-tau italic-square-root ARG:start ADDOP:minus italic-gamma ARG:end PUNCT:,

div.p: i.e. the Nambuâ€“Goto action for a string. This result is not completely correct due to the transformation problem of the fourâ€“dimensional metric tensor determinant Î·ğœ‚italic-eta\eta in (6) to the twoâ€“dimensional one Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gamma in (7) and absence of the correct definition of oneâ€“dimensional integrating. In this concept the pğ‘italic-ppâ€“branes are considered as the pğ‘italic-ppâ€“dimensional spaceâ€“like excitations of FFFEs, and the volume term (6) of the FFFE spaceâ€“time excitation yields the bosonic term of pğ‘italic-ppâ€“branes action analogically.

Consideration of the strings as the excitations of the quantized spaceâ€“time is the step to the understanding of the superstrings properties at the Plank distances. With this strings and pğ‘italic-ppâ€“branes consideration all these objects are identical at the Plank distances because the excitation of one element does not have dimension in the sense of FFFE spaceâ€“time.

The author thanks M.S. Orlov, A.V. Klochkov, E.V. Klochkova, A.V. Sokolov, G.S. Sokolova, A.B. Vankov for their friendly support during the work time, A.A. Amerikantsev, M.E. Golod, A.N. Lobanov for their technical assistance and M.A. Tyntarev for useful discussions.
